title: DevOps & Deployment
content:
Module 8, Lesson 1: DevOps & Deployment

Introduction

DevOps bridges development and operations, automating the path from code commit to production. CI/CD pipelines catch bugs before they reach users, containerisation makes deployments reproducible, and infrastructure-as-code ensures environments are consistent. Modern developers own their code in production.

Key Concepts

CI/CD Pipelines

Continuous Integration (CI): every code push triggers automated build and test runs. Merge only green builds. This prevents integration hell. Continuous Delivery (CD): every merge to main is automatically deployed to a staging environment. Continuous Deployment: every green build is deployed directly to production with no human gate.

Docker and Containers

Containers package an application with its dependencies into a portable, isolated unit. Docker builds images from a Dockerfile and runs them as containers. Unlike virtual machines, containers share the host OS kernel, making them lightweight. Docker Compose orchestrates multi-container development environments.

Environment Variables and Secrets

Never hardcode credentials in source code. Use environment variables for configuration that varies between environments (dev, staging, prod). Use a secrets manager (AWS Secrets Manager, HashiCorp Vault) for sensitive values. Rotate secrets regularly and audit access.

Summary

DevOps is a culture as much as a toolset: small, frequent releases, automated testing, infrastructure as code, and shared ownership of production. These practices reduce deployment risk and accelerate iteration.

quiz.question: What is Continuous Integration (CI)?
options: Manually deploying code to production
Automatically building and testing code on every commit to catch integration issues early
A method for integrating third-party APIs
A strategy for database migrations

quiz.question: What is a Docker container?
options: A virtual machine with its own operating system
A portable, isolated unit packaging an app with its dependencies
A cloud storage bucket
A type of database cluster

quiz.question: Why should you never hardcode credentials in source code?
options: It causes syntax errors
Source code is often version-controlled and accessible, exposing credentials to anyone with repo access
Credentials are too long to hardcode
Hardcoded credentials break CI/CD pipelines

quiz.question: What is the difference between a Docker image and a container?
options: They are the same thing
An image is a read-only template; a container is a running instance of an image
A container is built once; an image can be run multiple times
Images are for production; containers are for development

quiz.question: What does infrastructure as code (IaC) mean?
options: Writing application code that directly controls hardware
Managing and provisioning infrastructure through machine-readable configuration files
Using code comments to document server configurations
Automating code reviews with AI tools
